question: According to Le Chatelier's principle, in the reaction <katex>$\text{CO}(g) + 3\text{H}_2(g) \rightleftharpoons \text{CH}_4(g) + \text{H}_2\text{O}(g)$</katex>, the formation of methane is favoured by
(a) Increasing the concentration of CO
(b) Increasing the concentration of <katex>$\text{H}_2\text{O}$</katex>
(c) Decreasing the concentration of <katex>$\text{CH}_4$</katex>
(d) Decreasing the concentration of <katex>$\text{H}_2$</katex>
explanation: Increasing product (<katex>$\text{H}_2\text{O}$</katex>) or decreasing reactant (<katex>$\text{H}_2$</katex>) would shift it backward.
